articles.headline: Obama Presses Biggest Banks to Lend More
articles.snippet: As banks rushed to repay bailout money, they were in a stronger position to resist government demands that they change their practices.
articles.abstract: As banks rushed to repay bailout money, they were in a stronger position to resist government demands that they change their practices.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  President Obama pressured the heads of the nation’s biggest banks on Monday to take “extraordinary” steps to revive lending for small businesses and homeowners, prompting assurances from some financial institutions that they would do more even as they continued to shed their supplicant status in Washington.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Eric Dash

articles.headline: Rebuffing U.S., Pakistan Balks at Crackdown
articles.snippet: The Pakistani military has refused to turn on Siraj Haqqani, a Taliban warrior in Afghanistan and an asset of the Pakistani spy agency.
articles.abstract: The Pakistani military has refused to turn on Siraj Haqqani, a Taliban warrior in Afghanistan and an asset of the Pakistani spy agency.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Demands by the United States for Pakistan to crack down on the strongest Taliban warrior in Afghanistan, Siraj Haqqani, whose fighters pose the biggest threat to American forces, have been rebuffed by the Pakistani military, according to Pakistani military officials and diplomats.

articles.headline: Poll Reveals Trauma of Joblessness in U.S.
articles.snippet: Unemployment has caused major life changes and mental health issues for millions of Americans, a New York Times/CBS News poll found.
articles.abstract: Unemployment has caused major life changes and mental health issues for millions of Americans, a New York Times/CBS News poll found.
articles.lead_paragraph: More than half of the nation’s unemployed workers have borrowed money from friends or relatives since losing their jobs. An equal number have cut back on doctor visits or medical treatments because they are out of work.
articles.byline: By Michael Luo and Megan Thee-Brenan

articles.headline: Top Author Shifts E-Book Rights to Amazon.com
articles.snippet: Amazon will have the exclusive e-book rights to two books from Stephen R. Covey, a move that promises to raise the anxiety level among print publishers.
articles.abstract: Amazon will have the exclusive e-book rights to two books from Stephen R. Covey, a move that promises to raise the anxiety level among print publishers.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ever since electronic books emerged as a major growth market, New York’s largest publishing houses have worried that big-name authors might sign deals directly with e-book retailers or other new ventures, bypassing traditional publishers entirely.
articles.byline: By Brad Stone and Motoko Rich

articles.headline: In the Changeover at G.M., a New Hands-On Attitude
articles.snippet: In his first two weeks as chief of General Motors, Edward E. Whitacre Jr. has tried to shake up the automaker’s famously bureaucratic culture.
articles.abstract: In his first two weeks as chief of General Motors, Edward E. Whitacre Jr. has tried to shake up the automaker’s famously bureaucratic culture.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  When Edward E. Whitacre Jr., the new chief executive of General Motors, really wants to make a point, he tends to repeat himself.

articles.headline: Putting Obama on Hold, in a Hint of Who’s Boss
articles.snippet: In a sign of shifting power, three bank titans said bad weather stopped them from meeting with the president.
articles.abstract: In a sign of shifting power, three bank titans said bad weather stopped them from meeting with the president.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama didn’t exactly look thrilled as he stared at the Polycom speakerphone in front of him. “Well, I appreciate you guys calling in,” he began the meeting at the White House with Wall Street’s top brass on Monday.

articles.headline: Abu Dhabi Tightens Its Grip as It Offers Help to Dubai
articles.snippet: Dubai’s credit woes have given Abu Dhabi an opening to assert more control over its reeling neighbor. Abu Dhabi offered Dubai $10 billion lifeline on Monday.
articles.abstract: Dubai’s credit woes have given Abu Dhabi an opening to assert more control over its reeling neighbor. Abu Dhabi offered Dubai $10 billion lifeline on Monday.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON  By providing a $10 billion lifeline to Dubai on Monday, oil-rich Abu Dhabi has granted its debt-stricken neighbor a critical short-term reprieve from its creditors. But in doing so, it also appears determined to tighten the reins that Dubai has long resisted.
